_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN ? UPDATE (October 24, 2008)

CONOCOPHILLIPS COMPANY

SWEENY REFINERY 

 

I.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Sweeny Refinery has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training, written procedures, routine maintenance and inspection programs, and consideration of safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous chemicals. However, if a release should occur, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.


II.  DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Sweeny Refinery consists of four major facilities, which are linked by multiple pipelines and operates as a single unit. The main plant, near Old Ocean, Texas, is at the intersection of State Highway 35 and FM 524, about 60 miles southwest of downtown Houston. We also operate terminals and storage facilities in Freeport, Jones Creek, and San Bernard. The refinery covers approximately 3,000 acres at the four locations, the plant processes 247,000 barrels per day of crude oil and produces 125,000 barrels per day of gasoline. In our process, we use the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant, offsite consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics:  HF Acid, Chlorine, Ammonia-anhydrous 

Flammables: 1-Butene; 1-3-Butadiene; 1-Pentene; 2-Butene; 2-Butene-trans; 2-Butene-cis; 2-Pentene; 2-2-Dimethylpropane; 3-Methyl-1-Butene; Acetylene (ethyne); Butene; Carbon Oxysulfide; Ethane; Ethylene; Hydrogen; Isobutane; Isopentane; Isoprene; Methane; Normal Butane; Pentane; Propadiene; Propane; Propylene; Vinyl Acetylene (1-Buten-3-yne); 2-Methyl-1-Butene; Ethyl mercaptan


III.  HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

At the heart of the Risk Management Plan rule

is the requirement to conduct a hazard assessment to examine and communicate potential offsite effects of releases of regulated hazardous substances.  Two types of releases are to be considered, a Worst Case Scenario and an Alternate Release Scenario.  The WCS (representing a catastrophic event) is defined as a release with the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure, that results in the greatest distance to a specified endpoint.  The ARS represents a more credible, but still potentially significant, accidental release of a regulated hazardous material. It is also understood that active and passive mitigation systems can be considered in developing the ARS.  However, in some cases mitigation measures and systems may not have been included to its fullest extent in order to create potential worst-case alternate release scenarios.  In helping to establish the Alternate Release Scenarios that are more credible and likely, various information such as previous incident history, PHA failure scenarios, siting and spacing studies, etc. were considered. 
 
Note:  For Security purposes, the Offsite Consequence Analysis description and scenarios are not shown in the Executive Summary.


IV.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

The following is a summary of the general Accident Prevention Program in place at the Sweeny Refinery.  Because processes at the plant are subject to both EPA Risk Management Program Rule and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance, this summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the Accident Prevention Program.

A.  Employee Participation

Sweeny Refinery management encourages employees to participate in all facets of risk management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a Process Hazard Analysi

s (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the Sweeny Refinery?s Accident Prevention Program. In addition, Sweeny Refinery has a number of initiatives that address process safety and employee safety issues. These initiatives include forming problem-solving teams to promote both process safety and employee safety.  

Personnel representing operations, maintenance, office, and management work together on the Employee Excellence Team to represent facility employees involving the following areas: 

Behavior Awareness (Employee Behavioral Based Safety Process, Safety in Motion ? ergonomics)
Employee Ownership (traffic safety, general safety, safety concerns)
Waste Minimization (recycling programs, waste prevention and minimization)
Safety Standards and Procedures (review, edit, create, and audit)

B.  Process Safety Information

Sweeny Refinery maintains a variety of technical documents that are used for the safe and reliable operation of facility processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.   Specific departments within the facility are assigned responsibility for maintaining current and up to date process safety information. Process safety information documents are readily available for review and use.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). For specific process areas, the complex has documented safety related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, and composition) in the unit specific Process Safety Information (PSI). The teams verify the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

Numero

us technical documents are also maintained that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to confirm that safety features in the process are not compromised.

C.  Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

A formal process is established to help ensure that potential hazards associated with the various facility processes are identified and controlled.  Within this process, PHAs are conducted to systematically examine covered processes to identify potential process-related hazards and verify that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The HAZard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique is the primary method used to perform these PHA evaluations.  The PHAs are conducted using a team of people who have operating, maintenance and process engineering experience and expertise. 

Any PHA findings or recommendations identified are forwarded to the respective team management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained in the facility formal corrective action tracking database.

To confirm the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, Sweeny Refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These per

iodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer in operation. 

D.  Operating Procedures

Sweeny Refinery maintains written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, to include:  unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Formal processes and procedures are developed and maintained through the Training Team to help ensure operating procedures are periodically reviewed and certified annually as current and up-to-date. 

E.  Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Sweeny Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to confirm their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

F.  Contractors

Sweeny Refinery uses contractors as part of its regular work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities. Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to help verify contractors have the appropri

ate knowledge and skills to perform their work in a safe manner, are aware of the potential hazards in their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand and follow site safety rules and procedures, and inform plant personnel of any hazards they may discover during their work. Various information is communicated and provided to contractors to help accomplish this to include:
Process overviews,
Information regarding safety and health hazards (e.g., MSDSs),
Emergency Response Plan information,
Safe work practices applicable to contractor work activities.
 
In addition, Sweeny Refinery evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor company.  Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to help ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.  Meetings are held monthly with facility contractors and plant personnel to promote effective information sharing and to ensure site and work requirements are adequately communicated.

G.  Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSR)

As required by the OSHA PSM standard and in accordance with the EPA RMP Accident Prevention Program requirements, the Sweeny Refinery conducts PSSRs for any new facility or when existing facilities/processes are modified and requires a change in the process safety information. The intent of the PSSR is to confirm various features are in place prior to placing the equipment in service, such as:  proper hazard reviews, procedures, personnel training, and equipment is constructed and installed per design.  The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that Accident Prevention Program requirements are properly implemented.

H.  Mechanical Integrity

Sweeny Refinery has well established practices and procedures to help ensure covered process equipment is maintai

ned in a safe and reliable condition, to include:  pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems.  The basic aspects of this program include:  training, written procedures, inspections and tests, correcting identified deficiencies, and applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, and the applicable safe work practices necessary to perform their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures confirm work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training. Inspections and tests are performed to verify equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels). If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back in service (if possible), or an MOC Team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to verify the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance.  Quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs to help ensure new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Sweeny Refinery has developed a team based defect elimination process referred to as TPM (Team Perfected Manufacturing). The objective of this process is to eliminate equipment failures through predictive/ preventive maintenance and improve its operating reliability and safety.

I.  Safe Work Practices

Sweeny Refinery has well established written safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of

d by the PHA team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive immediate attention. All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete. The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained in the facility formal corrective action tracking database.



To confirm the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, Sweeny Refinery periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer in operation. 



D.  Operating Procedures



Sweeny Refinery maintains written operating procedures that address the various modes of process operations, to include:  unit startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Formal processes and procedures are developed and maintained through the Training Team to help ensure operating procedures are periodically reviewed and certified annually as current and up-to-date. 



E.  Training



To complement the written procedures for process operations, Sweeny Refinery has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive basic training in plant operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process specific duties and tasks. After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration, etc.) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they

n to the LEPC, the Sweeny Refinery also has a Mutual Aid System in place, the Emergency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) which is a sub committee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area. This system provides Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport area.  Also, the Brazoria Volunteer Fire Department and West Brazos Emergency Medical Services would provide assistance in the event of an emergency at the Sweeny Refinery. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year, hosted by a facility with other member facilities participating.





VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



New and/or planned upcoming events (some on-going) or changes to continue to improve safety at Sweeny Refinery include the following: 



Additional Emergency Shutdown Valves on Critical Equipment Lines.

Ongoing Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis and Reviews

Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis

State Implementation Plan - NOx Reduction Project

Facility Security & Vulnerability Assessments

Conducting Emergency & CAER Drills

Review & Updating of Tank Fire Preplans

Simulator Training Program for Operators

Alarm Management/Rationalization Project

Excess Flow Ball Checks for Sightglasses (technology upgrade) 

Fired Heater S/D Systems

FCC Shutdown Systems

these include:  control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lockout/tagout procedures to verify proper isolation of energy sources for equipment maintenance, procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, hot work permit and procedures, confined space entry procedures, and safety and emergency systems bypass permit/procedure.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

J.  Management of Change

Sweeny Refinery has developed written procedures to manage changes to covered processes.  These procedures require that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and changes to facilities that may affect a covered process, are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Hazard reviews are conducted to verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated as necessary to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.

K.  Incident Investigation

The Sweeny Refinery has established a formal incident reporting and investigation process to promptly investigate all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, chemical release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results

to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  All incidents and investigations are documented in the facility formal incident reporting and corrective action tracking database and retained in accordance with the company document records retention policy.

L.  Compliance Audits.

To confirm the Accident Prevention Program is functioning properly, Sweeny Refinery periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented.  Formal compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  In addition, periodic internal self audits are conducted to verify compliance on an on-going basis.  A report of any findings from the compliance audits are documented in the facility formal corrective action tracking database and tracked to completion.  The two most recent audit reports are retained.

M.  Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan

The Sweeny Refinery utilizes a Health, Safety & Environmental Management process called the Operating Excellence Plan.  This Plan helps drive continuous improvement in the HSE process and involve all employees of the facility.  This Plan is comprised of various HSE elements.  Action plans or enhancements for each element are identified and assigned to various groups/persons for implementation.  This Plan is reviewed and updated on an annual basis.  The elements of the Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan include:

EMPLOYEE OWNERSHIP & AWARENESS
TRAINING & DEVELOPMENT
SAFETY & HEALTHI 
COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT
WASTE MINIMIZATION
CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE
MONITORING & AUDITS
NONCONFORMANCES, INVESTIGATION & CORRECTIVE ACTION
STANDARDS & PROCEDURES
ENGINEERING DESIGN
POLLUTION PREVENTION
MECHANICAL RELIABILITY
RISK MANAGEMENT & EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS
OPERATING INTEGRITY

These elements, combined with the OSHA PSM elements

, help ensure a comprehensive Accident Prevention Program.

N.  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The processes at Sweeny Refinery involve potential hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP covered process at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, Sweeny Refinery has safety features on many processes to help quickly detect a release, contain/control a release, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

Release Detection

Gas Detectors (Hydrocarbon, H2S, etc.) with Alarms
Camera surveillance
Routine unit operator rounds/inspections of equipment

Release Containment/Control

Process relief valves that discharge to a flare system to capture and incinerate episodic releases
Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automatic)
Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, release detection)
Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)
Atmospheric relief devices
Diked areas
Check valves
Flare systems
Structural/equipment fire proofing
Relief valve maintenance procedures

Release Mitigation

Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
Deluge systems for specific equipment
Trained emergency response personnel
Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self?contained breathing apparatus)
Main control building is located outside of potential release areas
Water curtains for specific equipment
Siting and spacing initiatives
Emergency Isolation Valves
Emergency Activation Systems
Rapid Notify community alert network
Risk Based Inspection

V.  FIVE-YEAR A

CCIDENT HISTORY

Over the past 5 years, there have been no RMP events with offsite impacts. There have been several on-site RMP-related incidents involving injuries and/or property damage as follows: 

On 06/07/2004, an incident involving a flammable mixture release and fire from process Unit 26.1 CAT Feed Hydrotreater resulted in an employee recordable injury and property damage.  Employees were in the process of isolating an exchanger for maintenance to repair a tube leak when the exchanger pressured up and released the flammable mixture through a vent line and igniting.  

On 3/21/2005, an incident involving a flammable mixture from process Unit 9 Crude Still resulted in property damage.  While in the process of starting up the unit?s heater, fuel gas built up inside the heater firebox and ignited, causing an explosion inside the firebox.  No employee injuries or offsite impact was associated with this incident.    

The Sweeny Refinery has a formal written incident investigation process that is designed to identify root causes of incidents and develop appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Risk assessments are also made of incidents.  However, the Sweeny Refinery?s focus and philosophy is in the area of preventing accidents, and controls and measures are developed and implemented to help accomplish this.


VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Sweeny Refinery maintains written Emergency Response Procedures and Action Plans to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs

, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Sweeny Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is periodically reviewed and updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities. 

The overall Emergency Response Program for Sweeny Refinery is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. Sweeny Refinery has around the clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Periodic emergency drills are conducted that involve the LEPC and local emergency response organizations.  In addition to the LEPC, the Sweeny Refinery also has a Mutual Aid System in place, the Emergency Assistance Agreement Committee (EAAC) which is a sub committee of the Industrial CAER organization in the Brazosport area. This system provides Mutual Aid from other industry members in the Brazosport area.  Also, the Brazoria Volunteer Fire Department and West Brazos Emergency Medical Services would provide assistance in the event of an emergency at the Sweeny Refinery. The EAAC conducts emergency drills quarterly each year, hosted by a facility with other member facilities participating.


VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

New and/or planned upcoming events (some on-going) or changes to continue to improve safety at Sweeny Refinery inc

lude the following: 

Additional Emergency Shutdown Valves on Critical Equipment Lines.
Ongoing Facility Siting and Spacing Analysis and Reviews
Relief Valve and Relief Header Analysis
State Implementation Plan - NOx Reduction Project
Facility Security & Vulnerability Assessments
Conducting Emergency & CAER Drills
Review & Updating of Tank Fire Preplans
Simulator Training Program for Operators
Alarm Management/Rationalization Project
Excess Flow Ball Checks for Sightglasses (technology upgrade) 
Fired Heater S/D Systems
FCC Shutdown Systems

If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back in service (if possible), or an MOC Team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to verify the safe operation of the equipment.



Another integral part of the Mechanical Integrity Program is quality assurance.  Quality ass

urance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs to help ensure new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.



Sweeny Refinery has developed a team?based defect elimination process referred to as TPM (Team Perfected Manufacturing). The objective of this process is to eliminate equipment failures through predictive/ preventive maintenance and improve its operating reliability and safety.



I.  Safe Work Practices



Sweeny Refinery has well established written safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include:  control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, lockout/tagout procedures to verify proper isolation of energy sources for equipment maintenance, procedures for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, hot work permit and procedures, confined space entry procedures, and safety and emergency systems bypass permit/procedure.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.



J.  Management of Change



Sweeny Refinery has developed written procedures to manage changes to covered processes.  These procedures require that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and changes to facilities that may affect a covered process, are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Hazard reviews are conducted to verify adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated as necessary to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provide

d any necessary training on the change.



K.  Incident Investigation



The Sweeny Refinery has established a formal incident reporting and investigation process to promptly investigate all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, chemical release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to plant management and respective Teams for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  All incidents and investigations are documented in the facility formal incident reporting and corrective action tracking database and retained in accordance with the company document records retention policy.



L.  Compliance Audits.



To confirm the Accident Prevention Program is functioning properly, Sweeny Refinery periodically conducts audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the Accident Prevention Program are being implemented.  Formal compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  In addition, periodic internal self audits are conducted to verify compliance on an on-going basis.  A report of any findings from the compliance audits are documented in the facility formal corrective action tracking database and tracked to completion.  The two most recent audit reports are retained.



M.  Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan



The Sweeny Refinery utilizes a Health, Safety & Environmental Management process called the Operating Excellence Plan.  This Plan helps drive continuous improvement in the HSE process and involve all employees of the facility.  This Plan is comprised of various HSE elem

ents.  Action plans or enhancements for each element are identified and assigned to various groups/persons for implementation.  This Plan is reviewed and updated on an annual basis.  The elements of the Sweeny Refinery Operating Excellence Plan include:



EMPLOYEE OWNERSHIP & AWARENESS

TRAINING & DEVELOPMENT

SAFETY & HEALTHI 

COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT

WASTE MINIMIZATION

CONTRACTOR PERFORMANCE

MONITORING & AUDITS

NONCONFORMANCES, INVESTIGATION & CORRECTIVE ACTION

STANDARDS & PROCEDURES

ENGINEERING DESIGN

POLLUTION PREVENTION

MECHANICAL RELIABILITY

RISK MANAGEMENT & EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS

OPERATING INTEGRITY



These elements, combined with the OSHA PSM elements, help ensure a comprehensive Accident Prevention Program.



N.  Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



The processes at Sweeny Refinery involve potential hazards that must be managed to help ensure continued safe operation. The Accident Prevention Program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP covered process at the plant. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.



In addition to the Accident Prevention Program activities, Sweeny Refinery has safety features on many processes to help quickly detect a release, contain/control a release, and reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



Release Detection



Gas Detectors (Hydrocarbon, H2S, etc.) with Alarms

Camera surveillance

Routine unit operator rounds/inspections of equipment



Release Containment/Control



Process relief valves that discharge to a flare system to capture and incinerate episodic releases

Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual or automatic)

Automated Shutdown Systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature, release detection)

Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power

supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)

Atmospheric relief devices

Diked areas

Check valves

Flare systems

Structural/equipment fire proofing

Relief valve maintenance procedures



Release Mitigation



Fire suppression and extinguishing systems

Deluge systems for specific equipment

Trained emergency response personnel

Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self?contained breathing apparatus)

Main control building is located outside of potential release areas

Water curtains for specific equipment

Siting and spacing initiatives

Emergency Isolation Valves

Emergency Activation Systems

Rapid Notify community alert network

Risk Based Inspection







V.  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Over the past 5 years, there have been no RMP events with offsite impacts. There have been several on-site RMP-related incidents involving injuries and/or property damage as follows: 



On 06/07/2004, an incident involving a flammable mixture release and fire from process Unit 26.1 CAT Feed Hydrotreater resulted in an employee recordable injury and property damage.  Employees were in the process of isolating an exchanger for maintenance to repair a tube leak when the exchanger pressured up and released the flammable mixture through a vent line and igniting.  



On 3/21/2005, an incident involving a flammable mixture from process Unit 9 Crude Still resulted in property damage.  While in the process of starting up the unit?s heater, fuel gas built up inside the heater firebox and ignited, causing an explosion inside the firebox.  No employee injuries or offsite impact was associated with this incident.    



The Sweeny Refinery has a formal written incident investigation process that is designed to identify root causes of incidents and develop appropriate corrective actions to prevent recurrence.  Risk assessments are also made of incidents.  However, the Sweeny Refinery?s focus and philosophy is in the area of preventing accidents, and

controls and measures are developed and implemented to help accomplish this.







VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



Sweeny Refinery maintains written Emergency Response Procedures and Action Plans to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first?aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post?incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, Sweeny Refinery has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The Emergency Response Program is periodically reviewed and updated when necessary based on modifications made to plant processes or other plant facilities. 



The overall Emergency Response Program for Sweeny Refinery is coordinated with the Brazoria County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. Sweeny Refinery has around the clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire departments). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Periodic emergency drills are conducted that involve the LEPC and local emergency response organizations.  In additio
